repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4092

Inner classes isn't tested because they don't officially work
at this stage (see https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4572).
It should be tested if/when they're fully supported

comment_data.body: Is this needed? You're not using `old_body` below (probably by accident).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2557,6 +2560,24 @@ def visit_CClassDefNode(self, node):
         self.in_py_class = old_in_pyclass
         return node
 
+    def _body_without_directives(self, node, directives_to_remove):
+        # For things like cclass, cfunc, etc the directives
+        # should not keep propagating to nested funcs/classes
+        # after they have been applied. This function creates
+        # a CompilerDirectivesNode to ensure that
+        new_directives = Options.copy_inherited_directives(self.directives)
+        for d in directives_to_remove:
+            del new_directives[d]
+        old_body = node.body
+        if not isinstance(node.body, Nodes.StatListNode):
+            old_body = Nodes.StatListNode(node.pos, stats=[old_body])

comment_data.body: Not sure if this is enough. It probably is, currently, since we do not allow `cdef` functions as inner functions. But that may not be the case forever, and there's the auto-wrapping feature which might strike then. I think a tree assertion would make this safer.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -319,6 +319,32 @@ def test_cdef_nogil(x):
     return result
 
 
+@cython.cfunc
+@cython.inline
+def has_inner_func1(x):
+    # the inner function must remain a Python function
+    # (and inline must not be applied to it)
+    def inner():
+        return x
+    return inner
+
+
+with cython.cfunc:
+    def has_inner_func2(x):
+        # cfunc is not applied to "inner"
+        def inner():
+            return x
+        return inner

comment_data.body: No - probably not. It looks like body is expected to be a StatListNode anyway so it should be safe. I'll remove it.

comment_data.body:
Hmm. I wonder if that is the "expected" behaviour. I fully agree that a decorator should only apply to the decorated function, but the with-statement? I think one could argue both ways here. On the one hand, it should apply to the whole block, including everything that's in there. On the other hand, it is applied as part of the control flow, and the inner functions are not being defined in that context.

I guess it's best to not inherit it. That feels the safest and should be most easy to handle for users.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -319,6 +319,32 @@ def test_cdef_nogil(x):

+    # (and inline must not be applied to it)

+        return x
+    return inner
+
+
+with cython.cfunc:
+    def has_inner_func2(x):
+        # cfunc is not applied to "inner"

comment_data.body: The name sounds like it returns something, but instead, it _does_ something. So there should be a verb in here.

comment_data.body:
IMHO, they shouldn't be deleted but reset.

Did you consider letting `copy_inherited_directives` do this? Maybe even in general?

comment_data.body:
The tree assertion looks to break it (since it creates a CompilerDirectivesNode, which has the old directives still attached).

I think this is why I found this tricky last time I tried to look at this - `AdjustDefByDirectives` is too late because directives are already set up everywhere, but it's the logical place to do it since it's where you know that the `cclass/cfunc` compiler directives are being applied
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -319,6 +319,32 @@ def test_cdef_nogil(x):
     return result
 
 
+@cython.cfunc
+@cython.inline
+def has_inner_func1(x):
+    # the inner function must remain a Python function
+    # (and inline must not be applied to it)
+    def inner():
+        return x
+    return inner
+
+
+with cython.cfunc:
+    def has_inner_func2(x):
+        # cfunc is not applied to "inner"
+        def inner():
+            return x
+        return inner

comment_data.body:
This particular directives look to be distinguished by whether they exist or not (`if 'cclass' in self.directives`) so I think deletion is the right thing to do.

The trouble with `copy_inherited_directives` is that it completely breaks the "with statement" form (`with cython.cfunc`) because they're automatically removed from any function in the with statement.

comment_data.body:
I sort of agree here - the decorator clearly only applies to the function it's decorating, but the with statement feels more general.

The main reason not to do it is that it's hard to distinguish decorator from with statement

comment_data.body:
A bare `None` argument to a function call (or `True`, or `False`, etc.) is always difficult to interpret.
```suggestion
            return self.visit_with_directives(node.body, directive_dict, contents_directives=None)
```

comment_data.body:
Let's keep this simple. There's a comment and the code is clear enough, no need for an extra variable.
```suggestion
            node.body = Nodes.StatListNode(
                node.body.pos,
                stats=[
                    Nodes.CompilerDirectivesNode(
                        node.body.pos,
                        directives=new_contents_directives,
                        body=node.body)
                ]
            )
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1181,17 +1187,37 @@ def try_to_parse_directive(self, optname, args, kwds, pos):
         else:
             assert False
 
-    def visit_with_directives(self, node, directives):
+    def visit_with_directives(self, node, directives, contents_directives):
+        # contents_directives may be None
         if not directives:
+            assert not contents_directives
             return self.visit_Node(node)
 
         old_directives = self.directives
         new_directives = Options.copy_inherited_directives(old_directives, **directives)
+        if contents_directives is not None:
+            new_contents_directives = Options.copy_inherited_directives(
+                old_directives, **contents_directives)
+        else:
+            new_contents_directives = new_directives
 
         if new_directives == old_directives:
             return self.visit_Node(node)
 
         self.directives = new_directives
+        if (contents_directives is not None and
+                new_contents_directives != new_directives):
+            # we need to wrap the node body in a compiler directives node
+            new_node_body = Nodes.StatListNode(
+                node.body.pos,
+                stats=[
+                    Nodes.CompilerDirectivesNode(
+                        node.body.pos,
+                        directives=new_contents_directives,
+                        body=node.body)
+                ]
+            )
+            node.body = new_node_body

Given how this is used, it should rather be a set.
```suggestion
immediate_decorator_directives = {
    'cfunc', 'ccall', 'cclass',
    # function signature directives
    'inline', 'exceptval', 'returns',
    # class directives
    'freelist', 'no_gc', 'no_gc_clear', 'type_version_tag', 'final',
    'auto_pickle', 'internal',
    # testing directives
    'test_fail_if_path_exists', 'test_assert_path_exists',
}
```

comment_data.body:
And while we're at it, there's no need for this either.
```suggestion
        for name, value in directives:
```

This probably just fails because it receives the keyword argument twice. Remove the stars and pass the plain dict for copying, then it should work.
```python
directives=dict(node.scope.directives, annotation_typing=False)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -271,7 +270,7 @@ def handle_cclass_dataclass(node, dataclass_args, analyse_decs_transform):
     # generic objects and thus can accept _HAS_DEFAULT_FACTORY.
     # Type conversion comes later
     comp_directives = Nodes.CompilerDirectivesNode(node.pos,
-        directives=copy_inherited_directives(node.scope.directives, annotation_typing=False),
+        directives=dict(**node.scope.directives, annotation_typing=False),

comment_data.body:
This should use the same pattern as elsewhere, i.e.
```python
new_directives = dict(old_directives, **directives)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1194,10 +1194,11 @@ def visit_with_directives(self, node, directives, contents_directives):
             return self.visit_Node(node)
 
         old_directives = self.directives
-        new_directives = Options.copy_inherited_directives(old_directives, **directives)
+        new_directives = old_directives.copy()
+        new_directives.update(directives)

comment_data.body:
That definitely was an issue (and I tried something similar to what you suggested in https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4575/commits/84822a6db69f14459ea12601eafd3454952c9ad8).

Ultimately the real issue was that the `test_fail_if_path_exists` etc ended up being copied into these compiler directives nodes, and then causing test failures. So I came to the conclusion that `copy_inherited_directives` was serving a useful purpose.

I'm still not completely sure they should be needed, but it didn't seem like an easy fix to remove them
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -271,7 +270,7 @@ def handle_cclass_dataclass(node, dataclass_args, analyse_decs_transform):
     # generic objects and thus can accept _HAS_DEFAULT_FACTORY.
     # Type conversion comes later
     comp_directives = Nodes.CompilerDirectivesNode(node.pos,
-        directives=copy_inherited_directives(node.scope.directives, annotation_typing=False),
+        directives=dict(**node.scope.directives, annotation_typing=False),

comment_data.body: Either way, I think it's better to have a dedicated function for this, rather than spreading the assumption throughout the code base that calling `dict()` is enough.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -271,7 +270,7 @@ def handle_cclass_dataclass(node, dataclass_args, analyse_decs_transform):
     # generic objects and thus can accept _HAS_DEFAULT_FACTORY.
     # Type conversion comes later
     comp_directives = Nodes.CompilerDirectivesNode(node.pos,
-        directives=copy_inherited_directives(node.scope.directives, annotation_typing=False),
+        directives=dict(**node.scope.directives, annotation_typing=False),

commit.message:
Stop cfunc/ccall/class applying to inner funcs/classes

Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4092

Inner classes isn't tested because they don't officially work
at this stage (see https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4572).
It should be tested if/when they're fully supported

Change method, only apply to decorators

Now wraps the function body in a CompilerDirectivesNode

committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1644332465 +0100

Apply stylechanges from code review

commit.message: Compatibility with older versions of Python

Revert "Compatibility with older versions of Python"

This reverts commit 84822a6db69f14459ea12601eafd3454952c9ad8.

Revert "Try to remove copy_inherited_directives"

This reverts commit 204813a3b831d91e031aa7e2ee205b4c096c31da.

tree 573bd1804b6167eb378a1ec39ba012b2b266dd34
parent 45f872f0bfe111e21210d78fffc7345250ccb071

milestone.description:
Goals:
 New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
 Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
 Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
 Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Stop cfunc/ccall/class applying to inner funcs/classes
